title: Tyler through to Margaret River Pro quarter-finals after nearby shark attack
text:
April 16, 2018 / 1:18 PM / Updated an hour ago Tyler through to Margaret River Pro quarter-finals after nearby shark attack Reuters Staff 2 Min Read 
(Reuters) - Australia’s two-time world champion Tyler Wright put a nearby shark attack to the back of her mind as she progressed to the women’s quarter-finals of the Margaret River Pro on Monday. FILE PHOTO: Tyler Wright of Australia surfs during the women's World Surf League (WSL) championship at Guincho beach in Cascais, Portugal September 29, 2016. REUTERS/Rafael Marchante 
The third stop of this year’s World Surf League (WSL) Championship was put on hold after the first three heats of round two due to a nearby shark attack at Gracetown in Western Australia, just 15 kilometres away from the event. 
Two people were hurt in separate incidents, with one man airlifted to hospital for treatment. FILE PHOTO: Tyler Wright of Australia leaves the water during the women's World Surf League (WSL) championship at Guincho beach in Cascais, Portugal September 29, 2016. REUTERS/Rafael Marchante 
Following discussion between local authorities, safety teams and the surfers, the organisers decided to restart the competition with added ski and drone presence. 
Wright, the WSL champion for the past two seasons, overcame Paige Hareb of New Zealand with a score of 14.73 in round two before advancing past France’s Johanne Defay and Coco Ho of Hawaii in round three with 14.06. 
At the close of round three, surf conditions deteriorated causing further competition to be postponed, including cancellation of any activity on Tuesday. A reassessment will be made on Wednesday. Reporting by Hardik Vyas in Bengaluru; Editing by Christian Radnedge
